author: Canadian Press
title: Friends and family mourn the loss of Canadians killed by Hamas in Israel
text:
Friends, family and government officials have confirmed that at least seven Canadians were killed when Hamas militants conducted a series of attacks in Israel on Oct. 7.
Global Affairs Canada has said an eighthperson who was not a citizen but had deep ties to Canada also died in the ensuing conflict. Another Canadian, who has not been identified, died in Lebanon during the hostilities.
The Hamas attacks killed an estimated 1,200 people and militants took another 240 hostage, 105 of whom were released during a temporary pause in the violence at the end of last month.
As Israel continues its retaliation on Hamas in the Gaza Strip, authorities there say more than 20,000 Palestinians have now been killed.
Here's what we know about the Hamas victimswith ties to Canada:
Judih Weinstein Haggai
Judih Weinstein Haggai, 70, was out on an early-morning walk when Hamas started its attack, her family says.
She told members of her Nir Oz kibbutz that a militant on a motorcycle shot her husband and she was less severely wounded. The community was unable to dispatch an ambulance before militants arrived there.
Last week, the kibbutz confirmed Gadi Haggai, Judih's husband, died on Oct. 7, and on Thursday they confirmed Weinstein Haggai also died that day, and her body is being held in Gaza.
Weinstein Haggai was born in New York state but arrived in Toronto at the age of three, and moved to Israel 20 years later to live with her husband. She held Canadian, Israeli and American citizenships.
Weinstein Haggai was an artist and a volunteer who the kibbutz said "pursued many initiatives to advance peace in the region."
Her brother Larry Weinstein said the family is distressed by Israel's offensive in Gaza and the rise of hateful speech in Canada toward both Jews and Muslims.
"We're inspired by my sister, who believed in peace and believed in harmony," he said. "There can't be any kind of resolution when people are at each other's throats."
Vivian Silver
Vivian Silver, 74, was in her home on Kibbutz Be'eri near the Gaza border and talking on the phone with her son Yonatan Zeigen when they learned of the incursion by Hamas into Israel.
"We couldn’t grasp the incapability of the Israeli army to defend the civilians … we started to say goodbye because we realized this is probably our last words to each other," Zeigen later told a news conference organized by the Jerusalem Press Club.
He said they shifted their conversations to text messages so his mother could stay silent, and someone broke into her home. They said they loved one another before the messages stopped coming.
Zeigen said he had received information that she was taken hostage, and her phone had been geolocated in Gaza.
On Monday, his brother Chen Zeigen confirmed their mother's death. He said Israeli authorities told him the remains found earlier in the kibbutz had been identified as Silver.
He said his mother was born in Winnipeg and moved to Israel in 1974.
She dedicated her life to peacebuilding and fostering understanding between Israelis and Palestinians, he added.
She also volunteered to help children in Gaza access medical care in Israel.
Tiferet Lapidot
Tiferet Lapidot, 22, was a few days shy of her 23rd birthday and attending a music festival when the Hamas attack began.
Her cousin Oran Zlotnik remembered Lapidot as a charismatic and compassionate person who had travelled the world, taught in Africa and spent time in Australia before she returned to Israel in the fall.
Her uncle Harel Lapidot said she called her mother the morning of the attack to say she was hiding in a bush and to ask whether she should flee. Her cellphone was later tracked to the Gaza Strip, leading family to believe she was being held hostage. They then mounted a campaign to secure her freedom.
Zlotnik said that when the cellphone of one of Lapidot's friends, confirmed deceased, was also traced to Gaza, the family realized it was possible she wasn't a hostage.
Harel Lapidot said his niece's body was later identified and the family held a funeral.
"We know for a fact they were hunted," he said. "They ran away and they were hunted and killed."
Tiferet Lapidot was an Israeli citizen but her family was from Canada, including her father, Ohad, who was born in Saskatchewan.
Harel Lapidot thanked the Jewish community in Canada and MPs who had reached out to help and offer support. The family had a meeting with Foreign Affairs Minister Mélanie Joly while she was in Israel.
Netta Epstein
Israeli-Canadian Netta Epstein, 21, died when his home, Kibbutz Kfar Aza, came under attack.
His mother, Ayelet Shachar-Epstein, said he loved life. She learned the circumstances of his death from text messages he sent her in the moments before he was killed, and from his fiancée, Irene Shavit, who survived.
Netta Epstein was inside a safe room with Shavit, and he jumped on a grenade thrown in by the attackers.
Shachar-Epstein, who also lost her mother-in-law and two brothers-in-law in the attacks, described it as a terrorist invasion.
She said her son, who had worked with special needs youth, had returned home two months earlier after completing military service.
He was born in Montreal and was a Canadian citizen. Shachar-Epstein said many members of the family still live in that city.
Shir Georgy
Israeli Canadian Shir Georgy, 22, was killed by Hamas militants who ambushed the music festival near Kibbutz Re'im.
Georgy's aunt Michal Bouganim confirmed the death.
"We are currently a mess, heartbroken," Bouganim said in a Facebook message.
Bouganim shared a 22-second clip on her social media in which a terrified Georgy was seen sitting on a floor, with her back against a wall and surrounded by other festival attendees — some of them injured.
Georgy's funeral was held in Israel.
Adi Vital-Kaploun
Adi Vital-Kaploun, 33, was killed by Hamas militants in her kibbutz near the Israeli border with the Gaza Strip, said the Jewish Federation of Ottawa.
The group's CEO made a statement on behalf of Vital-Kaploun's family, saying the dual citizen has a large extended family in the Ottawa area.
The family said she died a hero, after convincing her killers to spare her two young children and warning her father and husband to stay hidden during the attack.
"Adi was a beautiful woman that brought love and lightness to the people around her, but also she was very focused and determined to make a beautiful life for her family," her cousin-in-law Aaron Smith said in an interview.
The family said she was an amazing mother and wife, always bringing love and laughter to their household.
She was also a talented dancer, saxophonist and basketball player.
After completing her master's degree in engineering, Vital-Kaploun excelled in her cybersecurity career, they said.
"We are mourning trying to process this unconscionable act of terrorism in her kibbutz and across the country," said the family, adding that they wish her memory to be "a blessing."
Ben Mizrachi
Canadian Ben Mizrachi was one of at least 260 people gunned down by Hamas militants at the music festival in southern Israel.
Mizrachi, 22, from Vancouver, was described as "larger than life with a big personality" in a statement by his former high school in B.C.
Ezra Shanken, CEO of the Jewish Federation of Greater Vancouver, said Mizrachi was about to start university in Israel after serving with the country's national defence force.
Hilit Nurick, a home economics teacher at King David High School in Vancouver, remembered Mizrachi as a "kind, wonderful, and community-minded" young man who had a positive influence on everyone around him.
Nurick said she and Mizrachi once put a large event together for more than 100 people at school.
"He was in charge of making Moroccan-style spicy fish stew. He brought his mother's recipe and shared it with everyone and taught us how to make it," said Nurick. "He was incredible, just an incredible human being."
Alexandre Look
Alexandre Look, who had recently celebrated his 33rd birthday, was among those killed while attending the musical festival.
Look, who lived in Montreal with his family before moving to Mexico, died a hero, his dad said in a Facebook post.
"Like a true warrior he left as a hero wanting to protect the people he was with," Alain Haim Look said.
Friend Lior Horovitz described him as a "once-in-a-lifetime person" who became like family during their five-year friendship.
In a phone interview from a town outside Tel Aviv, she said she and her boyfriend met Alexandre Look in Mexico. They became fast friends and would organize their vacations to meet up, either in Mexico or Israel.
He was a proud Jewish Canadian and a generous person who would do anything for his friends, she said.
"He's a person who loves people," she said. "He's the guy that's always going to help others, especially if they are Jewish."
This report by The Canadian Press was first published Dec. 28, 2023.
The Canadian Press

author: Matt Holiner Meteorologist
title: Severe thunderstorm watch for central Alabama Thursday
text: Next 12 Hours The threat of severe weather continues. Auburn and Opelika are now under a severe thunderstorm watch until 11 p.m. Thursday, along with much of the rest of central Alabama. Scattered showers and thunderstorms are expected again this evening. Heavy rain and lightning will occur in spots. A few storms are expected to produce damaging hail, possibly up to golf ball size, and damaging wind gusts up to 70 mph. Though unlikely, an EF0 or EF1 tornado can't be ruled out. Try to avoid unnecessary travel until 11 p.m. Make sure weather radios are turned on and cell phones are fully charged so you can be alerted if a severe thunderstorm warning is issued for your location. If one is issued, a severe thunderstorm is actively occurring and will soon move over you. Seek shelter indoors immediately. Another round of showers and thunderstorms is also expected very late tonight into early Friday morning. Isolated damaging wind, hail, and flooding will again be possible and another severe thunderstorm watch may be needed. author: Jaymie Hooper
title: Pawsitively purrfect Christmas gift ideas
text:
Sponsored by Petstock By Jaymie Hooper November 8, 2024 — 11.37am Save Log in , register or subscribe to save articles for later. Save articles for later Add articles to your saved list and come back to them any time.
Got it Normal text size Larger text size Very large text size Advertisement There’s no denying that Christmas is the most wonderful time of year, but once the lights are taken down, the tinsel is packed away and the presents are unwrapped and forgotten, the magic begins to wane. With the right presents, though, you can extend that magic well past December.
Thoughtful gifting is “nicer” than an expensive present.
From experiences that provide lifelong memories to charitable donations that uplift and empower others, these carefully curated gift ideas will cultivate a sense of joy that spreads far beyond your own four walls.
Hit subscribe Whether it’s a streaming service, curated kit or delivery box, a subscription is the gift that keeps on giving.
Ease your loved one’s mental load with a meal or snack-box delivery, encourage them to make time for their hobbies with a craft or gardening kit, treat their ears to a music or audiobook subscription or spoil them with a monthly wine or beer membership.
As well as offering ongoing enjoyment, subscription services also provide a deeper sense of personalisation — something we can all appreciate.
Adventure awaits Surprise your loved one with an experiential gift this Christmas and not only will you help keep their home clutter-free, you’ll help create cherished memories, too.
From hot-air balloon rides, horse-riding expeditions and wilderness escapes to concerts, fine dining and spa visits, there are plenty of experiences to choose from.
Advertisement It doesn’t need to be extravagant to make an impact, either. Keep it simple with a cooking class, paint and sip or movie night — anything that encourages them to break from routine and soak up the happy vibes.
The magic of giving
A charitable gift is priceless. Credit: iStock
Nothing encapsulates the spirit of Christmas more than giving to those in need. As well as bringing joy to your own life, and your recipient’s, you’re also giving the gift of a better future.
This year, the Petstock Foundation is making it easier than ever to do your part for people and pets in need with The Christmas Project .
“We know Christmas can be a difficult time for the most vulnerable people in our community, with many people experiencing even more financial strain, loneliness and increased anxiety during this time,” says Petstock Foundation head Jessica Curtis.
“At the Petstock Foundation, we understand the magic that pets and animals can bring to our lives, and our aim is to strengthen the rewarding bond between pets and people.”
To give the gift of a better future this Christmas, you can purchase a Petstock Foundation Christmas gift or Petstock Foundation product either in store or online until December 31.
“One hundred per cent of the proceeds from The Christmas Project will be donated to eight organisations nationwide,” Curtis explains. These charities include Guide Dogs Australia and Assistance Dogs Australia, as well as Lucy’s Project in NSW.
“Donations will enable charities to provide the gifts of sight, confidence, independence and empowerment for people who need them most,” Curtis adds. “Big or small, every gift is a chance to make a difference.”
Jewellery is forever Want to make a lasting impression? Explore the world of permanent jewellery. Unlike a diamond necklace or watch that’s only worn on special occasions, permanent jewellery is meant for everyday wear. Welded together while you’re wearing it, permanent jewellery (which often comes in the form of a simple chained bracelet, anklet or necklace) is the ultimate symbol of connection.
If your recipient prefers their jewellery with a clasp, opt for personalised pieces such as astrological pendants, birthstone jewels or timeless initials to keep it meaningful.
The gift of wellness Help your pal or partner nail their fitness goals with a gym membership or kick-start their journey with a one-month pass to a Pilates or yoga studio.
If they’re already locked in, get them excited to work out with some new accessories. Think weights and resistance bands, boxing gear, yoga blocks or a foam roller. Nothing says you care like investing in their health.
Thanks for the memories Collate your favourite moments into a photobook for your parents, siblings, friends or partner. A physical book will allow them to revisit your special memories time and time again, while a digital album will leave room for the highlights still to come.
As we navigate the hustle and bustle of the holiday season, let’s remember that the most enduring gifts aren’t always wrapped in paper. These gifts, whether grand or small, offer a lasting legacy of joy, connection and wellness that will continue to enrich lives long after the holiday season has passed.
To give the gift of a better future and purchase a Petstock Foundation gift or to learn more about The Christmas Project, click here .

author: Adrián Trejos"/>
title: Hay escasez de medicamentos psiquiátricos para reclusos de las cárceles en el eje cafetero
text:
Armenia
Hay alerta en el eje cafetero porque debido a la falta de medicamentos psiquiátricos varios reclusos presentan problemas y alteraciones en el comportamiento afectando la convivencia dentro de las cárceles.
Así lo dio a conocer el director de la penitenciaria de mediana seguridad Peñas Blancas de Calarcá, Quindío, mayor retirado Gonzalo Patiño que explicó “efectivamente ha habido inconvenientes con el suministro de los medicamentos psiquiátricos, ha habido faltantes, la empresa encargada que es Goleman está haciendo gestiones para poder entregar el suministro, pero se ha habido algunas situaciones de faltantes en algunos de estos medicamentos para los internos que están dentro del programa de psiquiátricos”
Esta empresa, como en un plan de contingencia, estamos con nosotros solicitándoles que prontamente nos resuelvan porque pues sí, se les ha entregado, pero ha habido algo que nos faltantes.
Falta de medicamentos provoca crisis en los detenidos El director del centro penal indicó “ el pasado lunes, a uno de los internos le hizo falta uno de los medicamentos psiquiátricos y efectivamente subió a la celda y prendió una colchoneta, afortunadamente, pues su reacción oportuna y rápida de los funcionarios con extintores y apagaron el fuego y únicamente, pues hubo ahí como 2 muchachos que sufrieron unas quemaduras muy leves que fueron atendidos por personal de Sanidad y ya pues ahí se superó como el hecho de presentar.
El problema de medicamentos en las cárceles del eje cafetero La falta de medicamentos no solo es este establecimiento el que ha tenido dificultad, también otros establecimientos de la regional, como lo son el establecimiento de La Dorada y el de Ibagué también han tenido dificultades con la entrega de medicamentos, han llegado algunos, pero no se ha restablecido, pues en su totalidad la entrega normal de los mismos estamos pensando a la espera que traten de normalizar ese tema.
Alerta por escasez de medicamentos para tratar enfermedades mentales en Armenia...

author: Lucy
title: BlackTrax Takes Ringling Bros.' Out of This World Production to the Next Level
text: In the groundbreaking production Out of This World by Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey®, CAST Group’s innovative BlackTrax real-time tracking system played a pivotal role in revolutionizing live entertainment. With a cast of 100 circus performers, many wore special BlackTrax beacons that allowed our cutting-edge technology to track their movements with absolute precision. This enabled programmable spotlights to follow each performer in real time, eliminating human error and illuminating them in a more theatrical, immersive way. By seamlessly integrating with lighting, video, and automation systems, BlackTrax created synchronized effects that responded instantly to the action on stage — setting a new standard for live show production. We’re incredibly proud to have been part of this reimagining of an iconic circus, pushing the boundaries of creativity and innovation.

author: Juan J. López
title: Salvi Jiménez peleará por el cinturón europeo en Inglaterra el 1 de marzo
text:
Secciones
Servicios
Destacamos
Salvador 'Salvi' JIménez (14-0-1, 6KO) presentó este jueves junto a Ryan Garner (16-0, 8KO) la 'Colisión en la Costa', en el estadio de fútbol del AFC Bournemouth de la Premier League. El combate, que se celebrá el próximo sábado 1 de marzo servirá pa dilucidar quién se enfundará el cinturón europeo del peso superpluma. Este está vacante tras la renuncia del francés El Hadri, con el que tenía que haber luchado ya el púgil vallisoletano, pero que está inmerso en conseguir el título africano.
Salvi, invicto, viajó a Inglaterra para presentar el combate con el boxeador local de 27 años, y considerado uno de los peleadores con más proyección del Reino Unido, que además competirá en casa y ante su público en el Centro Internacional de Bournemouth.
Garner, oriundo de Southampton, peleará cerca de casa por primera vez desde 2017, pero sus hazañas le han permitido construir una enorme base de apoyo con el respaldo de su club de fútbol local de la Premier League, cuyo estadio St Mary's está a dos minutos a pie de su gimnasio. «Estoy encantado de ofrecer una pelea para Ryan en un lugar mucho más conveniente para su creciente ejército de fanáticos», aseguró el promotor del combate, Frank Warren, en la rueda de prensa.
«Si hubiera un estadio en Southampton, habríamos estado allí hace mucho tiempo, por lo que nuestro objetivo es que Ryan continúe construyendo su carrera en Bournemouth. «La gente sabrá que siempre he sido un gran defensor de Ryan desde que se convirtió en profesional con nosotros a la edad de 18 años. Ha llevado un poco de tiempo llegar a este punto y ahora creo que está a punto de darse cuenta de su enorme potencial», valoró en relación a la que los ingleses consideran «prueba de fuego» ante Salvi. «Será una prueba muy dura contra Salvador Jiménez, un peleador invicto que se ha ganado su desafío al título», añadió el propio Garner ante las preguntas de la prensa local.
Ryan Garner (16-0, 8) se convirtió en campeón internacional de la WBC en agosto de 2023 cuando derrotó a Juan Jesús Antúnez en tres asaltos. Defendió con éxito contra el ex campeón británico Liam Dillon en mayo, ganando por decisión unánime, antes de enfrentarse a su prueba más dura hasta la fecha contra Archie Sharp en julio, repitiendo victoria.
Publicidad
Publicidad
Te puede interesar
Publicidad
Publicidad
Esta funcionalidad es exclusiva para suscriptores.
Reporta un error en esta noticia

author: , Palm Beach Daily News
title: Florida price gouging hotline activated as Gulf storm 97L approaches
text: Florida's attorney general activates price gouging hotline ahead of Gulf storm Invest 97L Attorney General Ashley Moody on Thursday announced that Florida’s "Price Gouging Hotline" is live after Gov. Ron DeSantis declared [a state of emergency](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/news/hurricane/2024/08/01/desantis-declares-florida-state-of-emergency-for-gulf-storm-97l-track-debby/74639334007/) in 54 of 67 counties – or 80 percent of the state. The moves comes as a [tropical wave](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/07/31/tropical-wave-in-atlantic-could-eye-gulf-coast-if-it-stays-weak/74625513007/), now designated as [Invest 97L](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/08/01/invest-97l-spaghetti-models-gulf-coast/74633466007/), could develop over the next week and head to the Sunshine State. If it develops, it could become [Tropical Storm Debby](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/07/31/tropical-wave-in-atlantic-could-eye-gulf-coast-if-it-stays-weak/74625513007/), the fourth named storm of the [2024 Atlantic hurricane season](https://www.tallahassee.com/story/weather/hurricanes/2024/07/29/tropical-cyclone-eyes-florida-heres-what-we-know-right-now/74587109007/). A press release from Moody's office said "price gouging laws are now in effect for the counties covered by the state of emergency: Alachua, Baker, Bay, Bradford, Calhoun, Charlotte, Citrus, Clay, Collier, Columbia, Dixie, Duval, Escambia, Flagler, Franklin, Gadsden, Gilchrist, Gulf, Hamilton, Hernando, Hillsborough, Holmes, Jackson, Jefferson, Lafayette, Lake, Lee, Leon, Levy, Liberty, Madison, Manatee, Marion, Monroe, Nassau, Okaloosa, Orange, Osceola, Pasco, Pinellas, Polk, Putnam, Santa Rosa, Sarasota, Seminole, St. Johns, Sumter, Suwannee, Taylor, Union, Volusia, Wakulla, Walton and Washington counties." Florida’s price gouging law applies to items and services essential to getting ready for, or recovering from, a storm within the areas of a declared state of emergency, the press release explained. That may include generators, food, gasoline, hotel rooms, ice, lumber and water. "Violators of the price gouging statute are subject to civil penalties of $1,000 per violation and up to a total of $25,000 for multiple violations committed in a single 24-hour period," the release said. “Invest 97L is expected to bring heavy rain and powerful winds to much of the state," Moody said in a statement. "To help Floridians prepare for this event, we are activating the price gouging hotline to accept reports of extreme price increases on essential commodities. As the system approaches, I’m urging Floridians to finalize their storm preparations, monitor weather reports and follow the guidance of local authorities.” For more information ∎ Anyone who suspects price gouging can report it to the Florida Attorney General’s Office by visiting [MyFloridaLegal.com](http://www.myfloridalegal.com) or calling 1(866) 9NO-SCAM. ∎ For more information on price gouging, read a PDF copy of "Attorney General Moody’s Scams at a Glance: Price Gouging" handout, online [here](https://www.myfloridalegal.com/sites/default/files/Price%2BGouging_Scams%2Bat%2Ba%2BGlance_v1a%5B1%5D.pdf), and in Spanish, [here](https://www.myfloridalegal.com/sites/default/files/Price%2BGouging_Scams%2Bat%2Ba%2BGlance_v1a_sp%5B1%5D.pdf). ∎ Moody recently released a [2024 Hurricane Preparedness Guide](https://www.myfloridalegal.com/sites/default/files/2024hurricanepreparednessguide.pdf). The guide contains information on tropical systems, preparedness checklists and tips for avoiding storm-related scams before, during and after a weather event. Brandon Girod of the Pensacola News Journal contributed. News Director Jim Rosica can be reached at [jrosica@tallahassee.com](mailto:jrosica@tallahassee.com). Follow him on X: [@JimRosicaFL](https://x.com/JimRosicaFL).

author: 网易
title: 建和美乡村 品非遗之美|山歌|村品|垫江县|薅秧歌|高峰镇_网易订阅
text:
6月12日，重庆市垫江县高峰镇大井村，当地村民在稻田间唱薅秧歌。
据了解，薅秧歌是流传于我国西南地区的传统民歌形式，源于水稻种植中的“薅秧”环节，农民在田间劳作时，为缓解疲劳、统一劳动节奏，即兴编唱的山歌。
村民在楼房间唱薅秧歌。
小学生在表演薅秧歌舞蹈。
近年来，垫江县高峰镇坚持“文化兴镇”，积极开展市级非物质文化遗产代表性项目“高峰薅秧歌”的培训、展示、体验等活动，并打造非遗传承基地、文艺创作基地和农文旅融合示范点，不断延伸文化产业链，有效推动乡村文化振兴，促进当地农文旅融合发展。
上游新闻签约摄影师 龚长浩 摄影报道
投稿邮箱：syxw@vip.163.com
topics: Arts, Culture and Entertainment->customs and tradition
